critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer use their fluffy tail as a warning signal to alert others of danger nearby.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have excellent memory and can remember food locations for years!

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes can adapt to many environments, from deserts to cities, making them highly versatile survivors.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and to keep warm in cold weather.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes are great climbers, often escaping predators by climbing treesâ€”unlike most other fox species!

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats can leap up to 10 feet high, helping them catch prey and escape predators quickly!

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines have sharp quills that detach easily to protect them from predators.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers build dams using sticks and mud to create ponds that protect their homes from predators.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges using plants, creating cozy underwater homes to stay safe and warm!

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks have waterproof fur that keeps them warm and dry while swimming underwater for food.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are skilled climbers and can even chase prey up trees!

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can close their ears and noses underwater to swim and hunt with ease!

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can find hidden nuts using memory and their keen sense of smell!

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their food caches to survive harsh winter months in North America.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks use cheek pouches to carry food, helping them stash snacks quickly for winter storage.

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally for camouflageâ€”brown in summer, white in winter!

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails can hop up to 10 feet in a single leap to escape predators!

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws that help them identify objects by touch, even underwater!

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums are immune to venom from snakes like rattlesnakes and cottonmouths!

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can spray a smelly liquid up to 10 feet to defend themselves from predators!

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide using a flap of skin called a patagium between their legs and body.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to navigate and find insects in complete darkness!

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, eating up to half their body weight each night!

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls hoot with a distinctive "Who cooks for you?" call, easy to recognize in forests!

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls can rotate their heads nearly 270 degrees without hurting blood flow.

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few birds where males and females sing beautifully.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout the winter!

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice often use sunflower seeds to crack open nuts and eat insects.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted nuthatches can climb down tree trunks headfirst to hunt for insects!

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers are the smallest woodpeckers in North America, about the size of a sparrow!

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers have a long tongue to extract insects from deep tree bark!

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated woodpeckers create loud drumming sounds by pecking large, rectangular holes in dead trees.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers use their strong beaks to drill holes and find tasty insects inside trees!

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 mph, making them one of North Americaâ€™s fastest birds!

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches eat mostly seeds and molt twice a year, changing bright yellow feathers to duller tones.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos are known for their bright white outer tail feathers, visible during flight.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches are one of the few wild birds whose males sing to attract mates year-round!

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches sing varied, cheerful songs to mark territory and attract mates during springtime.

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can run up to 20 miles per hour and fly short distances up to 55 miles per hour!

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse use air sacs on their necks to create a drumming sound for attracting mates.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform loud, trumpet-like calls that can be heard over great distances during migration.

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows are highly intelligent and can recognize human faces, remembering friends and foes alike!

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds from their environment, including human speech and animal calls.

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks have excellent eyesight, spotting prey from over a mile away while soaring high.

critters.name: Cooperâ€™s Hawk
critters.fact: Cooperâ€™s Hawks are fast flyers, often darting through trees to catch small birds and mammals!

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks are dabblers, feeding mainly on the waterâ€™s surface instead of diving deep.

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities and are known for their colorful, iridescent feathers.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration using strong, V-shaped formations to conserve energy.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can patiently stand still for minutes, hunting fish with lightning-fast strikes of their sharp beaks!

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted turtles can survive freezing temperatures by producing antifreeze-like chemicals in their blood!

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles can hold their breath underwater for up to 40 minutes while waiting to catch prey.

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill can breathe air by gulping it from the water surface during low oxygen conditions.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass can live up to 16 years and are known for their powerful, quick strikes!

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch have bright yellow bodies with dark vertical stripes, making them easy to identify underwater!

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike have sharp teeth and can strike prey with lightning-fast speed underwater.

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs whose loud calls signal the start of spring in many North American forests!

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can grow up to 8 inches long, making them one of North Americaâ€™s largest frogs!

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs can jump over 20 times their body length in a single leap!

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs can jump over 4 feet, using their long legs to escape predators quickly.

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can swim and often live near water, helping control amphibian and insect populations.

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to 30 minutes while hunting fish.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes with their colorful bands to avoid predators.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles, navigating using the sunâ€™s position in the sky.

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies have tail-like wing extensions that help confuse predators and protect them from attacks.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly up to 30 miles per hour, making them some of the fastest insects!

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings along their bodies, unlike dragonflies that keep wings open while resting.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use their glowing lights to attract mates and communicate with each other at night!

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of delicious flowers with their hive friends!

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can regulate their body temperature by vibrating their flight muscles, allowing them to fly in cooler weather!

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers hear through tiny eardrums located on their bellies, not their heads!
